Dear Mr. Watkins, Jr.:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on (date). Due
to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Implementation, Sustainability and Settlement Plan (MISEP) requirements, a written
corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules
are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15
days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are
unrelated to the staff person.
One of the seven new employee records reviewed contained a reference that was
dated outside the timeline established by this rule. In this example the employee
had an identified date of hire of 03/06/20 and one of the references was dated
03/07/20.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person
has not been named in a central registry case as the
perpetrator of child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in any
state where the person lived in the 5 years preceding hire.
One of the seven new employee records reviewed contained a central registry
clearance that was completed outside the timeline established by this rule. In this
example the employee had an identified date of hire of 03/06/20 and the central
registry clearance was completed 03/13/20. The clearance was clear.
R 400.12310 Initial evaluation.
(4) An agency shall document placement specifications
consistent with the information contained in the evaluation. The
placement specifications shall include the following:
(a) Age
3

One of the six current foster home files reviewed included an evaluation report with a
placement specification for age that was different from the subsequent license
(3706). In this example the report date was 08/26/20 with an age range identified as
5-7 years and the license identified an age range of 5-6 years.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(4) An agency shall document placement specifications
consistent with the information contained in the reevaluation.
The placement specifications shall include all of the following:
(d) Number of children preferred by the family
One of the six current foster home files reviewed included an evaluation report with a
placement specification that did not include the number of children appropriate for
the family. In this example the license identified a capacity of 3 and no capacity was
identified in the recommendations for a report dated 01/07/20.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
One of the six current foster home files reviewed indicated the recommendation for
the renewal of the license was not submitted at least 15 calendar days before the
expiration of the license. In this example the license had an expiration date of
12/19/20, the evaluation report was dated 12/16/20, and the transaction record
submitted for the renewal was signed 12/09/20.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(d) Notify all social service workers who have children placed
in the home that a special evaluation has been initiated.
One of the four special evaluation reports reviewed did not include documentation
the social service worker with children placed in the home was notified that a special
evaluation had been initiated. The intake of this evaluation was identified as
10/19/20.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(2) An agency shall inform foster parents of all of the following
before they are questioned or interviewed regarding a special
evaluation:
(c) That the foster parents may involve a person of their
choice in any interviews with them involving the special
4

evaluation if the involvement does not impede the timely
completion of the evaluation.
Two of the four special evaluation reports reviewed did not include documentation
the foster parents were informed they could involve a person of their choice in any
interviews with them if the involvement does not impede the timely completion of the
evaluation, or the reason why another person could not be involved.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(4) Before completion of the written report required by subrule (5
6) of this rule, an agency shall provide the foster parent with a
verbal summary of the preliminary findings at the conclusion of
the evaluation.
One of the four special evaluation reports reviewed indicated the foster parent was
not given a verbal summary of the preliminary findings at the conclusion of the
evaluation. The intake of this evaluation was identified as 10/19/20.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children are
interviewed, their last names shall not be included in the report.
One of the four special evaluation reports reviewed included the last name of a child
that was placed in the home. The intake date of this evaluation was 04/25/20.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker
that has children placed in the home.
Four of the four special evaluation reports reviewed did not include documentation
that a copy of the report was given to the social services worker that had children
placed in the home. This was discussed at the time of the exit conference that if the
worker was given a copy of the report the agency needs to provide appropriate
documentation for compliance with this rule.
R 400.12422 Foster care record.
(3) The record shall contain all of the following information:
(e) Change of placement documentation as required by
R 400.12405.
One of the two discharged youth records reviewed did not include change in
placement / discharge documentation as required by this rule. In this example the
5

youth had an identified date of discharge of 09/23/20 and the documentation for this
discharge was not located.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(1) An agency shall develop service plans with the child, the
child’s parents or legal guardian, the referring agency, and
other parties involved in providing needed services, or medical
care, unless the agency documents why any of the entities
have not been involved.
One of the six current foster child records reviewed did not contain adequate
documentation a service plan was developed with all the entities required by this
rule. In this example it was for the service plan with a time period of 12/7/20 to
1/04/21.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the
home.
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of the six current foster child records reviewed indicated an initial service plan
was completed outside the time frame identified by this rule. In this example the
initial service plan had an end date of 04/23/20 and it was completed 05/04/20.
One of the six current foster child records reviewed indicated an updated service
plan was completed outside the time frame identified by this rule. In this example
the end date of the updated service plan was 01/15/21 and this updated service
plan was not located at the time of this review.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(4) If an emergency change in placement is necessary, then all
of the documentation required in subrules (2) and (3) of this
rule shall be in the child’s record within 14 calendar days after
the change in placement.
Two of the six current foster child records reviewed the youth had a change in
placement that was not documented as required by this rule. The first example had
an identified change in placement 07/10/20 and the documentation for this change
was completed/dated 08/03/20. The second example had an identified change in
placement 06/08/20 and the documentation for this change in placement was not
located at the time of this review.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
6

(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed corrective
action plan, all social service workers who have children placed
in the home shall be notified there is a corrective action plan
and what is required of the foster parent in that plan.
One of the four special evaluation reports reviewed did not include documentation
the social services worker with children in the home were notified of what was
required of the foster parent in the corrective action plan.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) For a child under 2 years of age, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 3
months before being placed in foster care or a new
physical examination shall be completed within 30
calendar days after being placed in foster care.
One of the six current foster child records reviewed did not include a physical of the
foster child within the time frame established by this rule. In this example a physical
was due by 12/30/20 and the medical passport did not have a documented physical
at the time of this review.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12
months before placement or a new physical
examination shall be completed within 30 calendar
days after placement.
One of the six current foster child records reviewed did not include documentation
of a physical within 30 days of placement of the foster child as required by this rule.
In this example a physical was due by 4/25/20 and it was completed 8/20/20. It
was reported at the time of the exit conference that COVID 19 restrictions
contributed to this delay.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
7

(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
Two of the six current foster child records reviewed did not include documentation
of an updated physical being completed within the time frame established by this
rule. In the first example the most recent physical was dated 3/19/19 so an updated
physical was due by 5/19/20. In the second example the most recent physical was
dated 8/20/20 and the previous physical was dated 4/01/14. This agency did not
assume this case until 3/25/20.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any
treatment required for each child who is 4 years of age
and older, including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be
completed not more than 90 calendar days after
placement.
One of the six current foster child records reviewed did not include documentation a
dental examination had been completed within the time frame established by this
rule. In this example the youth had a completed dental exam dated 7/27/20 that
was due 6/25/20.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any
treatment required for each child who is 4 years of age
and older, including both of the following:
(ii) A dental reexamination shall be obtained at least
every 18 months, unless a greater frequency is
indicated.
One of the six current foster child records reviewed did not have a completed dental
exam within the time frame established by this rule. In this example the most
8

recent dental was completed 3/19/19 so an updated dental was due 9/19/20 and
there was no documentation this dental had been completed.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22). DHHS will maintain an operational
statewide automated child welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will be
the primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting requirements.
Documentation for some of the six foster child records reviewed were not uploaded into
the MISACWIS information system. Examples of the missing documentation for some of
the records were maintaining updated medical passports as required, timely uploading of
occasional treatment plans and Parent Agency Treatment Plans (PATP). The omissions
were occasional/the exception, and not a reflection of the overall documentation by the
agency. It is my assessment that case manager turnover was a contributing factor.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements except
for the following:
DHHS Policy 722-06B page 1-7 Family Team Meeting
FAMILY TEAM MEETING PROTOCOL Case planning is a cooperative effort in which
the child and family’s strengths and needs are assessed in partnership with the family,
caseworker, and other team members. FTMs are held to facilitate this process, which
involves developing a road map for moving children to permanence promptly, while also
addressing safety and well-being. The Michigan Family Team Meeting Protocol has
identified all required steps that must be accomplished during the FTM.
Two of the six current foster child records reviewed did not have adequate
documentation that a Family Team Meeting (FTM) was completed as a part of every
service plan review. Each of the two foster child records had inadequate documentation
of the completion of an FTM. The first example for the time period3/9/20 to 6/5/20, and
the second example for the time period 5/26/20 to 8/23/20.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
None Needed.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
There was one critical alert from the analyst’s visit to a relative home that did not have a
working alarm on the door of the home leading to the back yard where a pool was
9

located. The relative installed an appropriate alarm and video documentation was
received from the agency on 01/21/2021 confirming a working alarm.
EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
A substitute caregiver was involved in inappropriate drug usage and the foster parent
also had a drug screen testing positive for inappropriate drugs. The agency
submitted a recommendation for the revocation of the foster home license.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted a corrective action plan for the renewal evaluation completed
10/30/2019. Areas identified in noncompliance as a part of that evaluation were R
400.12306(4), R 400.12324(8), R 400.12326(1)(c)(d)(h), R 400.12327(6)(c), R
400.12418(6), ISEP 4.22 MISACWIS, and DHHS Policy 722-06 B Family Team
Meeting. Areas identified as repeat noncompliance as a part of this interim evaluation
are R 400.12327(6)(c), R 400.12324(8), ISEP 4.22 MISACWIS, and DHHS Policy
722-06 B Family Team Meeting.
VI. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
